sections: As annoying as it may seem, we need to talk about Elon Musk and Twitter. Up until this point, Elon‚Äôs Twitter takeover seemed like just another culture war sideshow ‚Äî until Twitter started banning journalists. On
I spoke with a leading digital rights advocate about the significance of these recent developments and what freedom of expression should look like in the digital age.
, the study group (including Senator Nina Turner) slog through the next five lessons from the Axelrod-Rove MasterClass. Axelrod and Rove try

hard to paint themselves as unique geniuses, but the study group provides the necessary historical context that entirely contradicts their message. It seems these political strategists still need to learn a thing or two about opposition research.
Learn more and find the episode links below.
Elon Musk‚Äôs Twitter Is The Opposite Of Free Speech

In light of Elon Musk‚Äôs Twitter flippantly banning journalists last week, David Sirota chats with Producer Frank and Jordan Uhl about the broader implications. Is this just another culture war sideshow, or is it the most forward-facing example of what happens when oligarchs control the public discourse?

Then, David is joined by Evan Greer, the director of the digital rights advocacy group Fight For The Future, who helps unpack the significance of Twitter‚Äôs implosion. Unlike other social media websites, Twitter is both a news source and a town square, which makes Elon‚Äôs unilateral control of the company all the more concerning. They also dig into the practicalities of content moderation and why freedom of expression is so crucial in the digital age.

Producer Frank and Andrew Perez discuss the ‚ÄúOne Thing‚Äù that‚Äôs been most on their mind recently. This week, Andrew lays out his opinions on the danger of censoring journalists online, and Frank discusses the negative effects of consumerism during the holiday season.
In the new episode of our ‚Äúeducational‚Äù series

, Dave, Josh, and their study buddy Senator Nina Turner make their way through the next FIVE lessons from David Axelrod and Karl Rove‚Äôs 24-part MasterClass on campaign strategy and messaging. We tried to warn them about consuming so much garbage in one sitting, but their commitment to education is unparalleled.

This week, the study group learn from the ‚Äúmasters‚Äù how to conduct campaign research and understand your voters. At least that‚Äôs what Axelrod and Rove claim they‚Äôre teaching. The study group offers their counter-narrative: David Axelrod accidentally stumbled across a once-in-a-lifetime presidential candidate who didn‚Äôt really need him, while Karl Rove used vile smears to destroy his political opponents. But hey, who actually remembers these things?
